instruction: What spectrum can be used to estimate soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters ?
Output: The related study used remote sensing spectrum to estimate soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to estimate soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters ?
Output: Extreme learning machine was used for spectral feature processing to estimate soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters.

instruction: What metric was chosen to estimate soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters  and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to estimate soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters was the Nitrogen Balance Index (NBI). The NBI can be used as a measure of the plant's nitrogen concentration.

instruction: How did the related study evaluate the power of high spatial resolution RGB, multispectral, and thermal data fusion in estimating soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters?
Output: The related study evaluated the power of high spatial resolution RGB, multispectral, and thermal data fusion in estimating soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters by using multiple low-cost sensors integrated on Unmanned Aerial Systems (UASs) to collect RGB, multispectral, and thermal images throughout the growing season. From these images, vegetation indices were extracted, a Crop Surface Model (CSM) was advanced, and a model to extract the vegetation fraction was developed. Spectral indices/features were then combined to model and predict crop biophysical and biochemical parameters using Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR), Support Vector Regression (SVR), and Extreme Learning Machine based Regression (ELR) techniques. The accuracy of the estimation was evaluated by comparing the predicted values with the actual values of the biochemical and biophysical parameters.

instruction: How did the related study assess the effectiveness of high spatial resolution RGB, multispectral, and thermal data fusion in estimating soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters for high-throughput phenotyping in precision agriculture?
Output: The related study assessed the effectiveness of high spatial resolution RGB, multispectral, and thermal data fusion in estimating soybean biochemical and biophysical parameters for high-throughput phenotyping in precision agriculture by using multiple low-cost sensors integrated on Unmanned Aerial Systems (UASs) to collect RGB, multispectral, and thermal images throughout the growing season. From these images, vegetation indices were extracted, a Crop Surface Model (CSM) was advanced, and a model to extract the vegetation fraction was developed. Spectral indices/features were then combined to model and predict crop biophysical and biochemical parameters using Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR), Support Vector Regression (SVR), and Extreme Learning Machine based Regression (ELR) techniques. The accuracy of the estimations was evaluated by comparing the results with actual measurements, and the root mean square error (RMSE) was used as a metric to assess the performance of the different sensor fusion techniques.
